newsitem.title: UK: U.S. stocks in London on hold ahead of jobs data.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks in London on hold ahead of jobs data.

text.p: U.S. shares were little changed on Friday as participants awaited key U.S. unemployment figures, due at 1330 GMT.
Dealers expect the Dow Industrials, which has dropped around eight percent in a little over three weeks, to push higher later today if the U.S. March jobless numbers are in-line with expectations.
"We could see a bit of a technical rally if the figures meet forecasts," one market maker said. "But I doubt any rally will be sustained. The market still looks like it needs more of a shake-out.
The U.S. non-farm payroll total is forecast to show an increase of 196,000 in March after rising by 339,000 the previous month, according to a Reuters poll of economists.
U.S. average hourly earnings, used by many participants as a guide to inflationary pressures, are expected to rise by 0.4 percent in March, after a 0.2 percent increase in February.
The Dow finished 39.66 points lower to 6,477.35 on Thursday, after trading nearly 100 points easier during the session.
The high-technology laden Nasdaq Composite rose 12.76 points or 1.06 percent to 1,213.76, helped by a firm showing in computer stocks.
Intel Corp, which rose $3-5/8 in New York on Thursday, was up $1/4 to $140-7/8, while Texas Instruments added $1/4 to $78-1/8.
Elsewhere, Philip Morris was down $3/8 to $114.
U.S. treasuries were also in a wait-and-see mood, with the June T-bond up 2/32 to 107-22/32 by 1005 GMT. The yield on the cash 30-year long bond was standing at 7.07 percent.
